title: 3  week3 - Remote sensing data
text:
3.1 Summary
This week mainly covered corrections, data joining, and enhancement. Atmospheric correction is a crucial step in remote sensing image processing aimed at removing the influence of the atmosphere on the image, thus obtaining more accurate surface reflectance information. The primary goal of atmospheric correction is to eliminate atmospheric scattering and absorption effects to quantify surface features more accurately (Jensen, 2007).
Due to the complexity of the topics discussed this week, I utilized mind mapping to record the key points of the lectures.

title: 3  week3 - Remote sensing data
text:
3.3 Reflection
The lectures this week are quite abstract and involve a lot of mathematical formulas when explaining the principles of correction and enhancement. However, they are crucial for later image processing and are key steps in subsequent analysis. If correct image processing is not performed from the beginning, it could lead to ineffective or erroneous analysis in the end.
The mathematical formulas for corrections may appear quite complex, but fortunately, each satellite comes with a user manual. This manual provides the correction formulas that can be referenced and utilized during the correction process. With the deepening of research, correction algorithms are continuously iterated and updated, resulting in improved image quality.
In practical operations, PCA analysis requires a large amount of computation and is very time-consuming. This week’s operations are still conducted in R, but I am also curious about how image processing is done in GEE.

title: 4  week4 - Policy
text:
4.1 Summary
This week’s lecture mainly explained the cases of remote sensing in solving practical problems and provided policy documents on urban development and planning around the world. I chose the area of food security from the Universal Sustainable Development Goals (11.3.1, addresses land consumption to population growth as an indicator), as China is also implementing strict arable land protection strategies to ensure food security. China’s central government has adopted remote sensing technology in land inspection since 2000 (Zhong, 2014). At the same time, I selected the previously worked Jinan City as the research object for this week. According to the Land Protection Law, Jinan has formulated the Overall Land Use Plan for Jinan City, with yellow areas in the map designated as agricultural land.









The land use planning of Jinan City

title: 4  week4 - Policy
text:
4.2 Applications
To monitor illegal construction using remote sensing technology, the first step is to obtain high-resolution remote sensing images. Currently, Shandong Province has launched the Dimensions 03/04 satellites, which are used for land surveys, geographic mapping, natural disaster monitoring, urban planning, and other fields. These satellites have relatively high spatial resolution and data acquisition capabilities, which can be used to monitor changes in arable land and protection efforts.
The next step is to establish a map database and perform pre-processing tasks such as object classification and feature extraction. Utilizing the features of buildings in remote sensing images, such as shape, color, texture, etc., combined with local building plans, land-use policies, and other information, rules for extracting illegal construction features can be formulated to automatically or semi-automatically identify illegal construction.
Finally, based on the extracted illegal construction features and verification data, machine learning, deep learning, and other methods can be used to establish a monitoring model to achieve automatic identification and monitoring of illegal construction.

title: 4  week4 - Policy
text:
4.3 Reflection
Although remote sensing can be used to monitor illegal land use activities, the identification of illegal construction is subject to complex policies, and due to the issue of model accuracy, many cases may result in misjudgments, requiring a significant amount of field verification work. Additionally, since the color of building roofs can lead to misidentification based solely on color recognition, it may be necessary to combine material recognition to more accurately identify illegal buildings.
Although SIBI has enhanced China’s central capacity to uncover illegal farmland conversion and weakened local governments’ abilities to conceal such activities, its impact on illegal farmland conversion is limited since it is merely a technical tool. Improvements in the governance structure of land inspection have also contributed to deterring illegal farmland conversion (Zhong, 2014).

title: 6  week6 - Google Earth Engine
text:
6.1 Summary
Google Earth Engine is a cloud-based platform for planetary-scale environmental data analysis. It is a public data catalog, compute infrastructure, geospatial APIs and an interactive app server.
Google Earth Engine (GEE) offers several key advantages:

Massive-scale geospatial processing. It contains planetary scale analysis and datasets which are provided by specialists, such as climate and weather.
Access to historical and near real-time satellite imagery and geospatial data. A wide range of open source satellite data such as Landsat, sentinel, High-Resolution Imagery, MODIS, etc. are available through GEE.
Analysis tools. What’s pretty amazing is that we can do all kinds of analyses like machine learning through Javascript coding, such as machine learning and statistical analysis capabilities for complex data interpretation.
Efficiency and rapid processing capability. The computation runs on google’s servers, and we borrow resources from the cloud for the computation, so it’s very efficient.

text:

6.2.1 Practical
This week, I conducted some basic operations on Google Earth Engine (GEE), focusing on the Delhi region in India. My activities included adding points and polygons. I loaded Landsat satellite imagery and used vector administrative boundaries from GADM for cropping. Since I loaded multiple images, I synthesized them into a single image using the method of mean.
































6.2.2 Case study: illegal waste disposal
Silvestri and Omri, emploied IKONOS satellite data to address the environmental challenges posed by uncontrolled landfills, particularly in areas experiencing rapid industrial growth. The method involves initial recognition using maximum likelihood classification, manual digitization of detected sites, and selection of the most likely lands using additional geographic and historical information.(Silvestri ,2008)


















Global Plastic Watch (GPW) is a digital platform that maps the world’s plastic pollution in near real-time using a unique combination of satellite imagery and artificial intelligence. The research employs a novel pipeline of neural networks(Pixel Spectrogram Classifier and Patch Classifier are used) that analyze spectral, spatial, and temporal data from Sentinel-2 satellites to detect plastic waste aggregations on land throughout Southeast Asia. This approach allows for the identification of plastic waste sites, monitoring waste site footprints over time, and generating metadata for each detected site.(Kruse, 2023)

title: 7  week7 - Classification Ⅰ
text:
7.1 Summary
This week I started performing classification operations in GEE. In class, we discussed how Land Use and Land Cover (LULC) distribution significantly affects Mean Annual Precipitation (MAP) and Land Surface Temperature (LST), identifying urban green spaces, and monitoring forests and illegal logging as examples. One machine learning method for classification is Classification and Regression Trees (CART), where classification trees are used to classify data into two or more discrete categories. Regression trees are used to predict a continuous dependent variable. Gini impurity is a measure used in decision tree algorithms for classification tasks. It quantifies the impurity or uncertainty of a dataset by calculating the probability of misclassifying a randomly chosen element if it were randomly labeled according to the distribution of labels in the dataset. However, this model can also suffer from overfitting. To avoid overfitting, techniques such as pruning, limiting maximum depth, setting minimum samples for splitting, setting minimum samples for leaf nodes, limiting the number of features considered for splitting, and using cross-validation can be employed to reduce the risk of overfitting in decision tree models.

title: 1  week1 - Introduction
text:
1.1 Summary

1.1.1 Remote sensing
This week mainly introduced the principles of remote sensing. Remote sensing is the acquisition of information about an object or phenomenon without making physical contact with the object (Schowengerdt, 2007).
Remote sensing can be divided into passive remote sensing and active remote sensing. In passive remote sensing, sensors detect and measure the radiation emitted or reflected by objects or surfaces. In active remote sensing, sensors emit their own radiation and measure the response from the objects or surfaces being observed.


1.1.2 Band
In remote sensing, a “band” refers to a specific range of wavelengths within the electromagnetic spectrum that is used to acquire data about the Earth’s surface or atmosphere. Each band corresponds to a particular portion of the spectrum, such as visible light, infrared, or microwave radiation. Each band provides unique information about the properties of the Earth’s surface or atmosphere. By combining data from multiple bands, remote sensing analysts can create composite images or datasets that offer a comprehensive view of the area being observed, enabling a wide range of applications in environmental monitoring, agriculture, urban planning, and other fields.


1.1.3 Resolutions
Remotely sensed data and applications will vary based on the four resolutions: Spatial, Spectral, Temporal, Radiometric (Jensen, 2007).
Spatial Resolution: the size of the smallest discernible feature in an image. It is usually expressed in terms of pixels per unit area or ground area covered by each pixel.
Spectral Resolution: the range of wavelengths or bands of the electromagnetic spectrum that a remote sensing system can detect.
Radiometric Resolution: the sensitivity of a remote sensing system to variations in electromagnetic radiation intensity.
Temporal Resolution: the frequency at which data is collected over the same area.
Remote sensing has multiple applications: land cover data set, Urban / green space coverage and accessibility, Pollution studies, Illegal logging, Forest fires, Temperature studies, Flooding / disaster response / building footprints.

Imposing these constraints can make the results of non-mixture analysis more physically meaningful and geographically realistic. The non-negativity constraint ensures that scores will not take on unreasonable negative values, while the unity constraint ensures that the sum of all scores is 1, representing the percentage distribution of land cover types within pixels. These constraints help improve the accuracy and interpretability of non-mixture analysis, making the results more closely aligned with actual geographical scenarios.
In spectral unmixing analysis, negative endmember fractions may occur due to several reasons: spectral similarity, spectral variability, noise effects, nonlinear mixing, and overfitting.

title: 8  week8 - Classification Ⅱ
text:
8.5 Dictionary

Sub pixel analysis. It determines the proportion or abundance of landcover per pixel.
Endmember: The spectral characteristics of pure land cover components constituting a mixed pixel.
Fractions: The fraction images obtained from unmixing, representing the fraction of each endmember in the mixture.
Sub-pixel: The situation in remote sensing imagery where individual pixels consist of multiple land cover types.
Unmixing: A remote sensing image processing technique aimed at decomposing the mixed spectral signatures within pixels into linear combinations of pure land cover spectra, or endmembers.
OBIA: Object Based Image Analysis. The ratio of the reflected electromagnetic radiation from a surface at different wavelengths.
Image Gradient: A commonly used image processing technique for detecting and highlighting edge and detail features in images. It determines whether a pixel belongs to an edge or to the interior of a region by computing the rate of change between its pixel value and those of its neighboring pixels.
Super Pixels: A commonly used image segmentation technique aimed at clustering adjacent pixels with similar properties into regions with unified characteristics.
Spectral Reflectance: The ratio of the reflected electromagnetic radiation from a surface at different wavelengths.
SNIC: Superpixels using N-Dimensional Iterative Clustering. The main idea of the SNIC algorithm is to simultaneously cluster pixels in both color and spatial domains.

title: 9  week9 - SAR
text:
9.1 Summary

9.1.1 SAR
A form of active data gathering, involves a sensor generating its own energy and subsequently measuring the energy reflected back following its interaction with the Earth’s surface. Longer antenna means narrower beam and a higher resolution. While too long antenna is not practical for a satellite sensor in space. Therefore, multiple acquisitions from a compact antenna are amalgamated to emulate a significantly larger antenna, thereby delivering data with enhanced resolution.









The table below notes the band with associated frequency, wavelength, and the application typical for that band.




















9.1.2 InSAR
It is mapping for ground movement detected through this phase shift. Movement is shown through an interferogram.


9.1.3 DInSAR
Differential Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar. It changes between two images in time. Looking at movement of land (uplift or sinking) with topography removed.


9.1.4 Polarization
In remote sensing, polarization refers to the orientation of the oscillation of electromagnetic waves during propagation. The direction of oscillation of electromagnetic waves can vary between the vertical and horizontal planes, a property known as polarization. Polarization states contains horizontal polarization (H), vertical polarization (V), or cross-polarization (HV or VH). (Jensen, 2007)

title: 9  week9 - SAR
text:
9.2 Application
I learned about a method for mapping and monitoring forest biomass in NASA’s SAR Handbook. It discusses the use of remote sensing, particularly SAR sensors at long wavelengths, for their sensitivity to Above Ground Biomass (AGB) and their capability to quantify and monitor carbon stocks effectively at a scale relevant to human activities.









Instances of allometric models for biomass derived from lidar data illustrate the process of translating airborne lidar observations into Above Ground Biomass (AGB). The diversity among these models indicates that focusing solely on a single parameter could lead to considerable variations in outcomes for different types of forests, akin to the variability observed in terrestrial allometric models.









Images from UAVSAR L-band polarimetry and polarization metrics over the La Selva Biological Station in the tropical forests of Costa Rica depict: (a) a composite color image using three polarization channels, highlighting regions of largely undisturbed rainforest spanning a mountainous area, with zones of lower biomass detected in the northern and southern extents of the imagery. (b) An image of the Radar Vegetation Index (RVI), where regions with denser forest biomass are marked in red, whereas agricultural lands, agroforestry, and regenerating forests appear in shades of green and blue. (c) An image of the Radar Forest Degradation Index (RFDI), which distinguishes the more pristine forests in deep blue from areas experiencing degradation, secondary growth, and lower biomass, depicted in lighter shades of blue, green, and red.

title: 9  week9 - SAR
text:
9.3 Reflection

The processing of SAR data at a lower level has historically presented a challenge due to the intricate and time-consuming preprocessing steps involved.
SAR images inherently contain speckle noise, which requires improvement in image quality through multi-looking processing and other despeckling techniques. Radiometric and terrain corrections also need to be applied to SAR data to eliminate errors caused by terrain undulations and changes in the angle of radar signal propagation.

title: 9  week9 - SAR
text:
9.5 Dictionary

SAR: Synthetic Aperture Radar. which is an active radar system that emits microwave signals and receives signals reflected back from targets to obtain images and information of the Earth’s surface or other target objects.
Radar pulse: the brief electromagnetic wave pulse emitted by a radar system.
EMR wave: Electromagnetic Radiation Wave.
Backscatter: The process where some of the energy from the signal emitted by the radar is scattered by a target object and returns to the radar receiver.
DEM: Digital Elevation Model. It is used to describe the elevation information of the Earth’s surface, excluding artificial or natural objects on the surface such as buildings, trees, etc.
DSM: Digital Surface Model. It describes the elevation information of all surface objects (e.g., buildings, trees, mountains) as well as the surface itself, including the elevation of all objects on the surface.
DTM: Digital Terrain Model. It is a more precise terrain model that describes the shape, elevation, and terrain below the surface.

title: 5  week5 - Temperature
text:
5.1 Summary
This week, I mainly focus on Heat Island, as well as Extracting temperature from satellite data. Urban heat island (UHI) refers to a localized area within a city or metropolitan area that experiences significantly higher temperatures compared to its surrounding rural areas. It primarily stems from more defined dark surfaces and less vegetation in urban areas. The urban heat island poses challenges to residents’ health, energy supply, economic development, and other aspects.
Currently, global policies aimed at reducing carbon dioxide emissions are being implemented to control global warming. The UN has developed the Beat the Heat Handbook to provide guidance measures for cities worldwide. During the class, various UHI reduction activities in different cities were introduced. Planting trees is one of the initiatives adopted by various cities, and remote sensing can assist us in identifying areas suitable for greening.
Remote sensing obtains surface temperatures through various sensors and techniques. One of them is using Thermal Infrared Remote Sensing. It utilizes the thermal radiation emitted from the Earth’s surface to acquire temperature information. Thermal infrared sensors measure thermal radiation in different wavelength ranges and infer surface.

title: 5  week5 - Temperature
text:
5.2 Application

5.2.1 Practical
In landsat 8 SR_B. represents Surface Reflectance bands, ST_B.* represents Thermal bands. Thermal bands typically include one or more bands used to measure surface temperature, such as ST_B10.


















The spatial resolution of MODIS is relatively low, typically ranging from 250 meters to 1 kilometer, making it suitable for monitoring large-scale surface temperature changes. Landsat, on the other hand, has a higher spatial resolution, typically ranging from 30 meters to 100 meters, making it suitable for monitoring surface temperature changes in smaller areas. MODIS has a higher temporal resolution, typically providing data daily, whereas Landsat has a lower temporal resolution, typically providing data every few days to weeks. Due to its higher temporal resolution and suitability for large-scale spatial resolution, MODIS is commonly used in fields such as global climate change monitoring, environmental monitoring, and weather forecasting. Landsat’s higher spatial resolution makes it more suitable for fine-scale surface temperature monitoring and surface feature identification, commonly used in areas such as land use/land cover change, urban planning, and resource management.




















5.2.2 Casa study:
Saputra (2022) focused on the investigation of the urban heat island (UHI) effect in Jakarta, Indonesia, during the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic. The study utilized remote sensing imagery from Landsat 8 to extract land surface temperatures and employed various methodologies for calculating UHI, including radiance conversion, brightness temperature, land surface emissivity, and correlation analysis with COVID-19 case distributions.

title: 5  week5 - Temperature
text:
5.3 Reflection
Weather Forecast

When it come to weather forecasting. Every city has a forecasted temperature, but for large cities, there can be temperature differences across different areas. By leveraging machine learning on remote sensing temperatures and forecasted temperatures, we can obtain more detailed temperature predictions for different regions within the city.

Urban Planning

I am also contemplating on urban planning. People have various orientations in urban plannin but currently, temperature is less considered in the initial design phase. Through machine learning, we can predict the future temperature of the built space after implementing different planning methods, in order to choose suitable methods to reduce the urban heat island effect.

Research use

Just like what Saputra did, we can obtain urban temperature data through remote sensing and then analyze it together with other data.

Limitations

Despite the unparalleled advantages of satellite images to explore the SUHI. Remotely-sensed LST is completely different from air temperature in terms of observation principles and altitudes, which makes SUHI not directly comparable to air UHI. (Zhou, 2019)
